journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Selection of suitable natural refrigerants pairs for cascade refrigeration system

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology (BHU), Varanasi, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur, India

author-notes.corresp: Jahar Sarkar, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology (BHU), Varanasi 221005, India. Email: js_iitkgp@yahoo.co.in

abstract.p: This study presents thermodynamic analyses and optimization of a two-stage cascade system employing a choice of eight natural refrigerants leading to the most suitable refrigerants pair for wide ranges of operating temperatures; the optimal pair was based on best system performance (cooling coefficient of performance) as well as best volumetric cooling capacity (compressor compactness). Out of the 56 possible combinations of high temperature and low temperature fluids with eight natural refrigerants – namely, ammonia, carbon dioxide, propane, propylene, n-butane, isobutane, ethane, and ethylene – the primary selection has been done based on the criteria of normal boiling point and critical point of both low temperature and high temperature fluids following the guideline of the operating temperatures of a refrigerant to be within its critical point and normal boiling point. All the selections have been made based on an optimum intermediate temperature leading to maximum cooling coefficient of performance for an individual pair. Effect of compressor isentropic efficiency on optimization and selection has been studied as well. Two selection charts along with tables have been developed, one for the highest coefficient of performance and another for the highest volumetric capacity; these design tools are expected to offer useful guidelines to select the best refrigerant pair for specific ranges of condenser and evaporator temperatures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
A suitable selection of refrigerants in a cascade system (employing two or more vapor compression refrigeration cycles in series as shown in Figure 1) in high temperature (HT) and low temperature (LT) cycles can provide the required LT while attaining good system performance. Synthetic refrigerants are being phased out worldwide to combat the twin menace of the ozone layer depletion and global warming; in view of this, several natural refrigerants are regaining their importance and are on a revival path. For cascade systems, lower temperature limit of the HT side is termed as intermediate temperature (IT), which has to be optimized as it influences system performance. There are several natural refrigerants, such as ammonia, carbon dioxide, butane, isobutane, propane, propylene, ethane, and ethylene, which are used in various refrigeration and heat pump applications. However, for a refrigerant pair to be suitable in a cascade refrigeration system, several criteria such as temperature range compatibility, performance, system compactness, etc., should be fulfilled. Figure 1.
Schematic of a two-stage cascade refrigeration system.

Theoretical as well as experimental analyses and optimization of ammonia–carbon dioxide cascade refrigeration system have been reported by several researchers.1–7 The energetic as well as exergetic analyses and optimization of CO2–C3H8 cascade system for simultaneous refrigeration and heating were reported by Bhattacharyya et al.8,9 DiNicola et al.10 experimentally determined the coefficient of performance (COP) of carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide binary mixture in LT cycle with R404a in HT cycle. Gong et al.11 experimentally studied the performance of two binary azeotropic mixtures and a ternary azeotropic mixture of R170 in the low-stage loop of a two-stage cascade system. Mafi et al.12 carried out exergy analysis for multistage cascade LT refrigeration systems with ethylene used in olefin plants. Kruse and Russmann13 reported a theoretical investigation on natural refrigerant based cascade systems employing nitrous oxide as LT refrigerant and compared it with an R23–R134a cycle. Bhattacharyya et al.14 studied the effects of design and operating parameters on system performance of a novel N2O–CO2 cascade system for refrigeration and heating. Kilicarslan and Hosoz15 studied energy and irreversibility analyses of a cascade refrigeration system for various refrigerant couples, although most of them were synthetic refrigerants. Kanoglu16 performed exergy analysis of propane–ethane–methane cascade refrigeration cycle used for natural gas liquefaction. These reported studies show that either analyses of one or two natural refrigerant pairs have been performed or comparison of natural refrigerants with chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) has been done; they clearly lack a comprehensive comparison among various possible natural refrigerant pairs.

This study presents thermodynamic analyses and optimization of IT for a cascade system employing a choice from eight natural refrigerants. Selection charts for suitable refrigerants pairs based on maximum cooling COP as well as volumetric capacity have been developed for a wide range of evaporator and condenser temperatures. Furthermore, the effect of compressor isentropic efficiency on system performance has been studied.

sec.title: Theoretical modeling and simulation
sec.p:
A schematic diagram of a two-stage cascade refrigeration system is illustrated in Figure 1 and the corresponding cycle diagram on the T-s plane is shown in Figure 2. The HT circuit absorbs heat from the LT circuit in cascade heat exchanger at evaporation temperature (known as IT) and rejects heat to ambient through the condenser. The LT circuit produces refrigeration at required low evaporator temperature (Tev), using the refrigerating effect of the HT circuit. In practice, there is a certain overlap between IT and condenser temperature of LT circuit (T3 > IT) and the difference between these two temperatures is called the overlapping temperature (OT). Figure 2.
Temperature-entropy diagram of a cascade refrigeration system.

Out of the eight natural refrigerants (ammonia, carbon dioxide, propane, propylene, n-butane, isobutane, ethane, and ethylene) considered in this study, there is the possibility of using each refrigerant as HT fluid or LT fluid, which yields 56 possible combinations of HT fluid and LT fluid. However, there are certain required characteristics of refrigerants which make them suitable for certain temperature range only. These important characteristics are normal boiling point and critical point of both HT and LT fluids. The operating temperatures of a refrigerant should be in between its critical point and normal boiling point. According to these guidelines, normal boiling point temperature (NBP) of refrigerants should be less than evaporating temperature of corresponding circuit, i.e. (1)Tev≥NBPLT,IT≥NBPHT

This ensures that no vacuum is created inside the evaporator, hence eliminating the possibility of entry of air and moisture into the system; additionally, operating at a temperature well above NBP would result in higher vapor density at compressor inlet, so that sufficient mass flow rate is maintained. The second criterion to be satisfied is that the critical temperature (CT) of refrigerants should be much greater than the condensing temperature corresponding to that circuit, i.e. (2)IT+OT≥CTLT,Tco≥CTHT

This will ensure that a reasonable refrigerating effect is achieved and that the cycle will be a subcritical one (condensation is nearly isothermal, which makes it close to Carnot cycle) leading to superior performance. Considering these characteristics, thermodynamic analyses have been carried out to obtain suitable refrigerant pairs for a wide range of condensing temperature of HT circuit and evaporative temperature of LT circuit.

The cascade refrigeration system has been modeled employing energy balance on each component. The following general assumptions have been made for the analysis.
The compression processes are adiabatic but not isentropic.
Refrigerant states at the cascade heat exchanger outlet for HT cycle and evaporator outlet are dry saturated, and that at condenser exit and cascade heat exchanger outlet for LT cycle are wet saturated.
Heat transfer processes in all the heat exchangers are isobaric.
Heat transfer with the ambient is negligible for all components except the condenser.
Isenthalpic expansion of refrigerants in expansion valves.
Negligible changes in kinetic and potential energies.

A mathematical model of the system is presented below. The cooling capacity of the evaporator is defined by (3)Q·ev=m·LT (h1-h4 ) where h is specific enthalpy. Compressor power consumption for the HT circuit is given by (4)W·HT=m·HT (h2h-h1h )
Whereas for the LT circuit, it is given by (5)W·LT=m·LT (h2-h1 )
The rate of heat transfer in the cascade heat exchanger is expressed as (6)Q·chx=m·LT (h2-h3 )=m·HT (h1h-h4h )
The mass flow ratio can be derived from the above equation given by (7)m=m·HTm·LT=(h2-h3)(h1h-h4h)
The rate of heat rejection by the condenser is given by (8)Q·co=m·HT (h2h-h3h )
The cooling COP of the system is expressed as (9)COP=Q·evW·LT+W·HT=(h1-h4)(h2-h1)+m(h2h-h1h)

The combined volumetric refrigeration capacity of the cascade refrigeration system (in terms of specific volume and enthalpy), signifying the compactness of combined LT and HT compressors, is defined by (10)Vc=Q·evm·LTv1+m·HTv1h=h1-h4v1+(m·HT/m·LT)v1h ⇒Vc=h1-h4v1+mv1h

Based on the theoretical model presented above, a simulation code was developed to investigate the effect of various operating and design parameters on the cascade system performance for different refrigerant pairs. This code was integrated with thermodynamic property subroutines to estimate properties of the working fluids such as ammonia, carbon dioxide, n-butane, isobutane, propane, ethane, propylene, and ethylene; these property codes were developed exclusively for this study based on correlations reported earlier in the literature.17–21 Efficient iterative procedures were employed to predict assorted state properties with reasonable accuracy. After sorting out suitable refrigerant pairs according to equations (1) and (2) and Table 1, performance parameters such as cooling COP and volumetric cooling capacity were calculated. Table 1.
Properties of natural refrigerants.
Refrigerant NBP (℃) CT (℃) Critical pressure (bar) Triple point (℃) Specific heat ratio Latent heat (kJ/kg)
Ammonia −33.35 132.3 113 −77.7 1.346 1370
CO2 −78.4 30.98 73.77 −56.6 1.3* 349.5*
Propane −42.39 96.98 42.47 −187.1 1.184 426.1
Propylene −48 92.42 46.65 −185 1.211 439.5
n-Butane −0.87 152 37.96 −135 1.119 385.3
Isobutane −12 134.7 36.4 −159.6 1.127 366.2
Ethane −88.84 32.18 48.72 –182.80 1.296 489.7
Ethylene −104 9.195 50.4 –169.16 1.358 482.5
Note: Specific heat ratio and latent heat are given at NBP except * given at −56℃.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The primary objective of the study was to identify the suitable pair of natural refrigerants which yields (i) maximum COP and (ii) maximum volumetric cooling capacity for given ranges of evaporator and condenser temperatures. For this exercise, overlap temperature was taken as 5 ℃ and the isentropic efficiency for both HT and LT compressors was assumed to be 0.78.2 The ranges of evaporator and condenser temperatures were taken as −25 ℃ to −85 ℃ and 25 ℃ to 55 ℃, respectively.

Previously reported studies showed that the cooling COP first increases and then decreases with IT and there exists an optimum value for IT that yields the highest COP, signifying best system performance for a given set of operating parameters. Additionally, the optimum IT is dependent on the refrigerants used and the operating and design conditions. All subsequent analyses done in this study are based on optimum IT, for comparisons based both on maximum COP and on volumetric cooling capacity.

sec.title: Selection of suitable refrigerants pairs based on maximum COP
sec.p:
The chart in Figure 3 shows the refrigerants pairs which exhibit the best system performance in terms of COP for the studied ranges of evaporator and condenser temperatures. NH3/propane and NH3/propylene pairs yield the maximum COP for Tev ranging from −25 to −42 ℃ and for all values of Tco. NH3/propylene pair exhibits the maximum COP for Tev ranging from −42 ℃ to −48 ℃ and for all values of Tco. For Tev within −48 ℃ and −72 ℃, NH3/ethane combination leads to the maximum COP for whole range of Tco. However, as Tev decreases further, IT falls below NBP of HT refrigerant and hence ammonia is not suitable for lower values of Tev, and propylene replaces ammonia as the HT refrigerant. Consequently, the propylene/ethane combination appears to be the best choice. Figure 3.
Chart for best refrigerants pair selection based on maximum COP.

The chart in Figure 3 should be used along with Table 2 which shows the variation of COP and corresponding optimum IT, ratio of mass flow rates and volumetric cooling capacity with change in evaporator and condenser temperatures for the refigerant pairs with maximum COP. For example, let us consider the case of natural refrigerant pair selection for an application where evaoporator temperature has to be maintained say at −65 ℃ and condenser temperature for heat rejection is 35 ℃. From the chart, NH3/ethane pair should be selected to obtain maximum COP and corresponding values of optimum IT and mass flow rates ratio as shown in Table 2 are −28.05 ℃ and 0.424, respectively. −25 55 NH3/propylene 7.85 0.394 1.802 1211
−35 55 NH3/propylene 3.16 0.413 1.510 890

The HT circuit can employ high boiling point and high CT refrigerants so as to ensure positive pressure inside cascade heat exchanger and reasonable refrigeration effect respectively. From Table 1, it is clear that latent heat for ammonia is much higher than other refrigerants, which makes it the best refrigerant for the HT circuit. Although ammonia also has a high value of γ ( = 1.346), which leads to high isentropic work, but the relatively large value of latent heat compensates for it in the calculation of COP. The limiting factor for use of ammonia at lower values of Tev is its normal boiling point (around −33 ℃) and hence becomes unsuitable for the HT circuit if IT falls below − 33 ℃. Next to ammonia, ethane and ethylene have high values of latent heat but their low boiling points and low CTs make them unsuitable for HT circuit use. The next best option as the HT circuit refrigerant is propylene followed by propane. Since, propylene has lower NBP (–48 ℃), it can be used at lower values of Tev, where ammonia and propane cannot be used. Although butane and isobutane have lower values of latent heat, they also have comparatively lower values of γ leading to less isentropic work and higher COP. However, their much higher NBP makes them unsuitable as HT refrigerant.

The use of a lower NBP refrigerant ensures a smaller compressor displacement in the LT circuit and hence a higher COP. Moreover, low NBP ensures a positive pressure inside the evaporator even at lower values of Tev and thus prevents any possible leakage of air and moisture into the system. Based on NBP and the corresponding hfg values (Table 1), it is evident that propane and propylene offer great potential even as LT refrigerant for Tev values greater than their NBPs. Thus, propane and propylene both will be suitable as the LT refrigerant in combination with ammonia as the HT refrigerant. These NH3/propane and NH3/propylene pairs yield similar values of maximum COP due to their comparable values of latent heat and specific heat ratio. Since propane and propylene have NBP of −42 ℃ and −48 ℃, respectively, they cannot be used in the LT circuit for Tev values below these temperatures respectively and ethane, ethylene and CO2 appear to be a good choice for LT refrigerant. The triple point temperature of CO2 prevents its use as LT refrigerant below a Tev of −56 ℃. While both ethane and ethylene have similar values of hfg, a higher value of γ for ethylene leads to a lower COP compared to that with ethane as the LT refrigerant, and thus ethane appears to be the best choice for the LT circuit. Thus, NH3/ethane and propylene/ethane pairs lead to the maximum COP at lower values of Tev. The equation of a straight line which separates NH3/ethane and propylene/ethane region in the chart is given by (11)Tev=-0.572Tco-57.83

Table 2 shows the variation of optimum IT and the corresponding COP and Vc for refigerants pairs exhibiting the maximum COP. As Tev decreases while keeping Tco at a fixed value, maximum COP and optimum IT decrease. As an illustration, with ammonia as HT and ethylene as LT refrigerants for Tco = 25 ℃, OT = 5 ℃, ηC = 0.78 (for both HT and LT compressors), as Tev varies from −85 ℃ to 5 ℃, maximum COP and optimum IT vary as shown in Figures 4 and 5. Again as Tco increases, keeping Tev fixed, the maximum COP decreases while optimum IT increases almost linearly. For example, we may consider a cascade system with ammonia as HT and ethylene as LT refrigerant, with Tev = –25 ℃, OT = 5 ℃, ηC = 0.78 (for both HT and LT compressors), as Tco is varied from 20 ℃ to 55 ℃, maximum COP and optimum IT varies as shown in Figures 4 and 5. Thus, as the cycle temperature lift increases, the COP decreases due to decrease in refrigeration effect and increase in work input. From Figures 4 and 5, it is also clear that optimum IT bears an approximately linear relationship with Tco and Tev for a certain pair. Most of the previously reported correlations for optimum IT are also linear.1–7 Hence, it is possible to establish linear correlation of optimum IT for suitable refrigerant pairs at various temperature ranges. Figure 4.
Variation optimum IT with condenser temperature for maximum COP.
Figure 5.
Variation of maximum COP with condenser temperature.

sec.title: Selection of suitable refrigerants pairs based on maximum volumetric capacity
sec.p: The volume of suction vapor required per unit of refrigeration is an indication of the size of compressor. Alternatively, refrigeration capacity per unit volume of suction vapor may be used to estimate the required compressor capacity for the same refrigeration capacity employing various refrigerants. Usually reciprocating compressors are used with refrigerants with high pressure and small volumes of suction vapor, while a centrifugal compressor is used with refrigerants at low pressures and large volumes of suction vapor. For a single-stage vapor compression cycle, refrigeration capacity per unit volume of suction vapor can be used to estimate the size of a compressor and a comparison can be made between various refrigerants. However, for a cascade system, there are two compressors – one in the HT circuit and another in the LT circuit. Size of compressor directly impacts its initial manufacturing cost and up to some extent the operating cost as well (for a reciprocating compressor there will be higher frictional losses for a large size compressor and more power is required to run it compared to a smaller compressor). Thus, compressor size should be as small as possible for unit refrigeration capacity. Currently available literature on cascade systems has employed refrigeration capacity per unit volume of suction vapor of LT compressor to estimate the size of the LT compressor. However, this does not provide any idea about the size of the HT compressor which together with the LT compressor forms the total power requirement of the cscade system. Hence, a new defination is introduced in this study (equation (10)).

A chart (Figure 6) has been prepared which lists the refrigerants pairs which yields the highest values of volumetric capacity for a wide range of condenser and evaporator temperatures. This chart should be used in combination with Table 3 to evaluate the maximum volumetric capacity and the corresponding values of COP, optimum IT and mass flow rate ratio. From this chart, it is evident that CO2, ethane, and ethylene as LT fluid and Propylene as HT fluid are the best in terms of Vc. Optimum IT increases with increase in both Tev and Tco, whereas maximum Vc is mainly affected by Tev (Figures 7 and 8). Restrictions for maximum operating pressure and pressure ratio are also important issues in selecting a refrigerant pair. In view of the modern developments related to high pressure sustainability, the maximum pressures for selected pairs (Tables 2 and 3) are within allowable limit. However, ammonia yields more pressure ratio (maximum of 21) for some operating temperatures (compressor efficiency degrades with increase in pressure ratio), which can be avoided by replacing it with the next best refrigerant propylene or using multistage compression. Figure 6.
Selection chart for best refrigerants pair based on volumetric refrigeration capacity.
Figure 7.
Variation of optimum IT with evaporating temperature for maximum Vc.
Figure 8.
Variation of maximum volumetric capacity with evaporating temperature.

sec.title: Effect of compressor isentropic efficiency on optimization and selection
sec.p:
It may be observed that compressor efficiency has a distinct effect on system performance, and in fact COP is linearly related to isentropic efficiency. Let us consider a case where ethane and ethylene are the LT refrigerants, with Tev = –70 ℃, TC = 40 ℃, OT = 5 ℃. As the compressor efficiency is changed, there is a large variation in system COP as shown in Figure 9. Ammonia has been used as the HT refrigerant in both cases and the same isentropic efficiency has been applied to both HT and LT compressors. As compressor efficiency increases, system COP increases linearly. For the ammonia/ethylene system, as compressor efficiency is increased from 60 to 90%, system COP increases almost by 62%. Similar is the trend for the ammonia/ethane based system as well. Thus compressor isentropic efficiency is very important, and its effect is more pronounced when temperature lift is rather large and COP is low. There is a slight increase in the value of optimum IT with change in copmpressor efficiency. Hence, the compressor isentropic efficiencies have negligible effect on selection charts based on both maximum COP and maximum volumetric capacity (Figures 3 and 6). Figure 9.
Effect of compressor isentropic efficiency on system performance with NH3/ethane and NH3/ethylene.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this study, the selection of suitable natural refrigerants pairs for a cascade system has been made in sequential stages stated as follows. Initial selection is based on its operating temperatures which should be in between its NBP and CT. Next, optimization of IT is carried out leading to the maximum cooling COP, and a final selection of refrigerant pair based on best system performance along with the best volumetric cooling capacity. The following summarized comments and conclusions characterize this study.
Charts have been prepared based on the maximum COP and the maximum Vc after optimizing IT with respect to maximum COP for a wide range of Tco and Tev values; these are expected to offer useful guidelines for selecting a refrigerant pair for particular applications.
Based on the maximum COP, ammonia was found to be the best HT refrigerant for higher value of Tev, while propylene appears to be the best working fluid for lower value of Tev.
Based on the maximum COP, propane and propylene are the best as LT refrigerant for higher value of Tev, while ethane exhibits the best perfomance for lower value of Tev.
Refrigerants with high NBPs are best suited as HT refrigerants, while for LT circuit, refrigerants with lower NBPs yield the best performance.
A comparison has been made based on the best Vc, which is related to the size of compressors for unit refrigeration capacity and it was found that propylene/CO2 pair is the best for high values of Tev followed by propylene/ethane and propane/ethylene pair for low values of Tev.
As expected, an increse in isentropic efficiency of compressors increases COP linearly; however, there has been a little effect on the optimum IT and refrigerant pair selection.
The best COP as well as the best volumetric cooling capacity values increase with increase in operating temperatures keeping fixed temperature lift.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
